meeting_annotations.speaker: Neil Kelleher
meeting_annotations.transcript: to the enzyme turnover as a probe through development. Is that is that feasible?
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker uses expansive hand gestures while talking, then rests his chin on his fist in a thoughtful pose.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Masha Kamenetska
meeting_annotations.transcript: If I could just ask so and also echo what people have been saying. We've been talking about kind of spatial resolution, resolving the substrate, and now I think we're talking about dynamics. So I think which of those or and there's probably more aspects of enzyme activity you're most interested in would determine the probe, kind of going back to what Gabriella was saying, there are trade-offs, there are some fundamental physics limitations. But do you care more about dynamics and time resolution or do you care more about spatial resolution or specificity would determine maybe the kind of tool you'd want to use.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker touches her forehead while thinking and uses hand gestures to delineate the different scientific concepts she is summarizing.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stefano Di Talia
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah I guess depends on the biology I would say. I mean for us the resolution is the cell, right? So because we work in multicellular tissue and we really can't. So you don't need that much more that standard resolution is plenty but it may not be the case for more complex question or question of how signal propagate within a cell, right?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephanie Gupton
meeting_annotations.transcript: And the same goes for time, right? Like how much time like if you're thinking about growing part of a cell or part of an organ that's much that's a long time scale.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker's video is slightly out of focus.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stefano Di Talia
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah and we have done we work with embryos where things happen in minutes and we zebrafish adults where things happen in days. So so it's been very very different. It's been sort of interesting on a theoretical point of view we see similar principle of waves as a mechanism to propagate signals but there is almost a four order of magnitude in the speed of the waves we have in fly embryos versus zebrafish adults which in itself it's interesting how they can control all those time scales.
meeting_annotations.other: The speaker rests his head on his hand while talking, appearing deep in thought.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ross Wang
meeting_annotations.transcript: From what I have seen I think both spatial and temporal resolution are very important. Usually in most proposal or papers, spatial temporal has been combined as even a single word. So I just want to chime in regarding Neil's question. Then you ask about enzyme turnover. So it's also related to where inside the cell, which specific organelle and in certain space. And then you have to a certain detection or the tool will have to differentiate that enzyme's fluorescence level like substrate fluorescence level from the other counterpart or the rest of the cells. Because probes could be everywhere but although nowadays there's a trend to develop organelle specific probe, organelle targeted probes too.
meeting_annotations.other: A whiteboard with scientific diagrams and chemical structures is visible in the background.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephanie Gupton
meeting_annotations.transcript: I guess I one thing that this has kind of made me think of is like we have all this data like from you know looking at genomes of enzymes and then we have all these data from proteomic screens of like this is the phosphorylated proteins in the cell and this is the ubiquitinated proteins in the cell but there's not really been a linkage between enzymes and all those substrates and I wonder if there if that would be something that like computational biology could start to bring together those two sides and that that might reveal more I don't know a lot more biology for all of us and chemistry.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Neil Kelleher
meeting_annotations.transcript: Wow 100%. I mean you know there's so many of these lists right and but how do you make them functional? I heard the word in a conference a year ago junk phosphorylation. I was like oh wow that expresses what I've been feeling in the proteomics community. It's just like I have 30,000 phosphorylation sites. Good for you. Which ones are functional versus bystander?
